description: RN's science flagship: your essential source of what's making news in the complex world of scientific research, scandal and discovery. The Science Show with Robyn Williams is one of the longest running programs on Australian radio. One single audio file of each program - good for continuous listening.
title: The Science Show - Full program podcast

episodes.title: The profound versus the preposterous - Life vs loony.
episodes.description:
What is life? 
Revisiting the great Carlos hoax

episodes.title: Three Prime Minister’s Science Prize winners
The Prime Minister’s Science Prize
episodes.description:
Prime Minister’s Prize for Science awarded for discovery of gravitational waves.
Celebrating Ruby Payne-Scott and the birth of radio astronomy.

episodes.title: Hope in Hell?
episodes.description:
Hope in Hell
Working towards bigger, better lithium batteries
Should scientists take a position in the US election?
The Human Body Survival Guide

episodes.title: No more fish?
episodes.description:
Fish of the eastern Pacific
Wild fish catch easily replaced by aquaculture
Barramundi breeding restocks our tropical northern rivers
National Youth Science Forum boosts young people keen on science
Fixing the climate emergency must start now - Johan Rockström part 8, final

episodes.title: The North Pole, gentle robots and the future of AI
episodes.description: 2020 Nobel Prizes. Ten steps for best chance of climate stability - Johan Rockström part 7. Designing our AI future. New roles for robots. The Pilbara - test ground for NASA with school students keen to learn about their ancient land.

episodes.title: Three exceptional women
episodes.description: Lecture - Futures Past and Possible: Histories of and for Tomorrow

episodes.title: Venus - another prompt for the regeneration of science?
How to eliminate CO2 emissions from agriculture? The answer lies in the soil!
episodes.description:
US west coast ablaze.
The Amazon regulates the planet’s climate and we’re burning it - Johan Rockström part 4.
Soils can play a major role in storing carbon.
Conservation co-op provides connection to community and nature.
Meteorites bring information about the early solar system.

episodes.title: Pipsqueak dinosaurs – How did they become top monsters?
episodes.description:
Urgent action required to steer clear of climate tipping points - Johan Rockström part 3.
Thermal bricks could assist transition to renewable energy.
Young people at risk from online gambling.
Dinosaurs - from pipsqueaks to monsters.
Children’s book features adventures with reptiles.

episodes.title: Can you have a BBQ 40,000 years before people land?
episodes.description:
Stressed planet sending clear warning signs – Johan Rockström part 2.
The nudge which opened the door to mathematics.
Shells and blackened rocks on the Victorian coast dated to 40,000 years before first people believed to be in Australia.
STEM Superstar says go for it!
Patient Zero

episodes.title: Lithium potential for Australia and time running out climate change action
episodes.description:
Window closing for action to stabilise the Earth’s climate. 
Cleaner air delivers LA health and economic benefits.
Lithium processing a new opportunity for Australia.
Children’s book about surgeon Fiona Wood.
STEM Superstar prompts government probe on masks.
South Georgia Island once rat infested, becomes a rat-free bird sanctuary.

episodes.title: New ideas about our food choices and how taste and pleasure have helped drive evolution
episodes.description: What really controls our eating decisions? How our bodies tell us what to eat. Taste and pleasure of food offer a new way to understand evolution.

episodes.title: Shall we join the quantum revolution?
episodes.description: Scientists urged to keep waving the flag. UNSW launches new degree in quantum engineering. Startup building the infrastructure for quantum computing. Reducing the data, energy and emissions of big data computing. Designing the computers of tomorrow. Lasers support our modern way of life.

episodes.title: Dr Dolittle turns 100 and the complex behaviour of birds
episodes.description: Dr Dolittle turns 100, The Bird Way: a new look at how birds talk, work, play, parent and think and flies dance to lure their mate

episodes.title: The seaweed revolution and keeping brains fit
episodes.description: The stars that time forgot – at the edge of our galaxy. Protect your hippocampus with exercise, diet, socialising and sex. Rope-like filaments common to rouge brain proteins. Kinky proteins suspected cause for Alzheimer’s. Microalgae the basis for fuels, food and more. New seaweed processing plant opens in southern NSW. Singing frogs bid farewell to Mike Tyler.

episodes.title: The history of Boeing and the future of passenger  flight
episodes.description: Basics of naming in biology, museum returns human remains to traditional communities, the history of Boeing and the future of passenger flight, space rockets being developed in Queensland.

episodes.title: The Pilbara - used by ancient people and NASA, blown up by Rio Tinto
episodes.description: Pilbara used by NASA to prepare for Mars missions. Pilbara Aboriginal site destroyed by Rio Tinto. Predicting earthquakes. Evolution of angiosperms. Mike Tyler reflects on Joseph Banks.

episodes.title: The Frog Man remembered + global genomes
Are physicists bonkers?
Could there be a Goldilocks Universe? And how to save our seahorses
The Science Show shares some of its favourite books
episodes.description: From mathematics and mammoths to the woman who found out what stars are made of: Robyn Williams and Carl Smith talk about books with Eddie Woo, Sharon Giltrow, Zofia Witkowski-Blake, Craig Cormick, Danielle Clode and Chris Flynn.

episodes.title: Vale the professor of everything
Climate grief 3 - How comedians approach climate change
Tiahni Adamson - first ever Indigenous Time at Sea Scholarship recipient and how hard it is to read faces.
Fear for the Amazon, and a chance to compost yourself!
episodes.description: The plunder and destruction of the vast Amazon forests have been so terrible, that by 2035, they will cease to be a sink for CO2. The burning was so bad last year that the holocaust featured on the cover of The Economist magazine. This week The Science Show receives its first report from Ignacio Amigo who lives in Manaus and writes for the journal Nature.

episodes.title: Climate grief 2 - Singer-songwriter Missy Higgins
episodes.description: Talk to our top creative people – writers, musicians, comedians even (especially them) and you find most are deeply concerned about the massive threats to environment. Last week we heard the concerns of marine scientist Ove Hoegh-Guldberg. This week one of Australia’s greatest young singers, Missy Higgins, tells Dr Jonica Newby how climate grief has been at the heart of her most recent songs. Don’t Look Down is a breathtaking example. Missy describes the emotions – and the science – that have inspired her. She comes from a scientifically-minded family and is struggling with the choices confronting most families in this turbulent, uncertain world.

episodes.title: Climate grief
episodes.description:
This week professor Ove Hoegh-Guldberg from the University of Queensland, a world-renowned marine scientist and contributor to IPCC assessments, talks about the likely loss of the Great Barrier Reef. How does a determined, optimistic researcher keep going amid the upsets.

WARNING: This episode contains language that may cause offence to some listeners.

episodes.title: A tribute to Australian doctor Catherine Hamlin who dedicated her life to helping young African women damaged by traumatic  births
episodes.description: Catherine Hamlin was born in Sydney. She worked in Ethiopia pioneering medical treatment for young women damaged by unsuccessful childbirth. In 2000, Pauline Newman visited Catherine Hamlin and her famous hospital in Addis Ababa. Catherine Hamlin died in March 2020 at the age of 93. By way of tribute today we revisit Pauline’s program from nearly 20 years ago.

episodes.title: PREVIEW RN Presents — Hot Mess: Why haven’t we fixed climate change?
episodes.description: It has been just over three decades since warnings were first raised about global warming. The 20 hottest years on record have all occurred in the last quarter century. So why aren’t we serious about climate change? Richard Aedy goes looking for answers in a 4-part series on RN - Sunday mornings at 8am from 3rd May and podcast.

episodes.title: Jane Goodall, Christof Koch and an app to save dollars
episodes.description: How can Jane Goodall have hope for the future, especially for the animals she loves, when the news about extinctions is so bleak? As The Hope, a 2-hour film about Jane and her life, is launched this week by National Geographic Jane joins Robyn on The Science Show to discuss the film, her work and her hope.

episodes.title: Three superstars – and one’s only 18!
episodes.description: Patrick Webster was head boy at Albany Senior High and became deeply involved with the waters of SW Australia. Which led him to think about climate (yes, we are obsessed by the virus, but this is even bigger). Hear Patrick’s speech to a packed hall in Albany and realise there is hope.

episodes.title: Asteroids chock full of water, multiverses, and our planet full of life – deep as you go!
episodes.description: A large asteroid carrying plenty of water will be worth millions of dollars we’re told. But it’s not sloshing around. Instead, the water is carried in chemical form within the rocks themselves. Now Dr Katarina Miljkovic from Curtin University has analysed gases coming off asteroids when they are bombarded as they fly through space. She has found there will be enough water to support human explorers when they venture through the galaxy.

episodes.title: A schoolgirl’s plea, a flying monster and kids on screens
episodes.description: Despite shutdowns caused by that virus, we are gaining little benefit in emissions reduction. Rebecca Ford, age 16, who’s at The Senior High School in Albany WA tells The Science Show  why she is so concerned and how much young people need our support. Yes, we are distracted, but climate change won’t go away and could make corona seem like a mere passing sniffle if we’re not careful.

episodes.title: Fear! Should we be frightened? ...and survive?
Why is it so cold in here?
episodes.description: Besides the virus, what’s bothering people in offices and cabs around the world? Well, it’s freezing. Especially for women. Tom Chang at the University of Southern California did the tests and found there’s a marked drop in productivity if people are uncomfortable because the air-conditioning is berserk. He published his findings and was astounded to find there were millions of responses. Is there a gender difference? Do men in suits really not feel the freeze? Can we afford to waste the energy on unwanted ice boxes to work in?

episodes.title: The arts meet the sciences - and ads in the sky?
episodes.description:
White dwarfs reveal composition of gobbled planets
How light pollution impacts animals
Plan to create advertising messages in the sky using satellites
Tragedy of the commons now being played out in space
The arts and sciences dance together with inspiring results
Curiosity the cornerstone for artists and scientists

episodes.title: Our superginormous black hole is hungry again
The grid is wobbling – what to do? And here comes the WA Scientist of the Year, and he’s running!
The USA, and Australian forests under extreme pressure
A wire around the world
The formula - the new science of success
A journalist’s view of The Australian’s anti-science campaign, changes in energy and transport, and a boost for innovation.
The Coastline – as vital as your skin. Keep it healthy or we die.
How bees see, how fish change their sex and a poem on bushfires, climate, politics and society
Science Extra: 2019 in space
episodes.description: The first image of a black hole, Apollo 11 celebrations, and the successes and failures of 2019's satellite missions. Plus what to expect from the Mars-bound missions in 2020.

episodes.title: Carl Zimmer explores the history of our understanding of heredity
Science Extra: 2019 in environment
episodes.description: Droughts, fires, and discussions around climate change intensified in 2019. A recap of the year in environment news, and a glimpse of what's to come in 2020.

episodes.title: Melting ice and burning forests signs of a changing world
episodes.description: 3. The importance of Antarctica for the Earth’s climate

episodes.title: Science Extra: 2019 in science
episodes.description: From quantum 'supremacy' to deep life, catch up on the big themes from a busy year of science. Plus will scientists build a brand new eukaryote in 2020?
